pathway: Pharmacy First – Acute Otitis Media (AOM) – Clinical Pathway (children and young people 1–17 years)
notes: Use shared decision-making and clinician global impression throughout.
Provide safety‑netting information for all patients and share links to evidence on antibiotics (NICE).

decisionTree.title: Patients presenting with signs and symptoms of acute otitis media
decisionTree.question: Are there acute onset symptoms suggestive of AOM?

youngerChildren: Holding, tugging or rubbing of the ear
Non-specific: fever, crying, poor feeding, restlessness, behavioural changes, cough, rhinorrhoea

yes.title: Otoscopic examination (gateway point)
yes.question: Are otoscopic signs of AOM present?
details: Distinctly red, yellow or cloudy tympanic membrane
OR moderate–severe bulging of tympanic membrane with loss of normal landmarks and air-fluid level behind TM
OR perforation of the tympanic membrane and/or sticky discharge in the external auditory canal

yes.title: Consider risk of deterioration or serious illness
yes.question: Does the patient meet ANY high-risk/serious illness criteria?

systemicOrSeriousIllness: Signs of a more serious illness
highRiskComorbidity: Significant heart, lung, renal, liver or neuromuscular disease
suspectedAcuteComplications: Brain abscess (severe headache, confusion/irritability, muscle weakness)

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Consider NEWS2 and escalate to A&E/999 if life-threatening.
Refer to General Practice or other appropriate provider.

no.title: Eardrum perforation / otorrhoea
no.question: Is there otorrhoea (after perforation) or suspected/confirmed eardrum perforation?

next.title: Penicillin allergy?
next.question: Is there a reported penicillin allergy?
notes: Acceptable allergy sources: patient/carer or National Care Record.

yes.title: Pregnancy status (only relevant for 16–17 years)
yes.question: Is the patient aged 16–17 and pregnant or pregnancy suspected?

yes.title: Erythromycin (for penicillin allergy, pregnancy 16–17 years)
formulations: Oral suspension/solution 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL, 500 mg/5 mL (standard and sugar-free) x 100 mL
yes.route: Oral, with water just before or with food
yes.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Clarithromycin (penicillin allergy)
formulations: Oral suspension/solution 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL x 70 mL
no.route: Oral with water (with or without food). Avoid bitter after-taste by drinking juice/water after suspension.
no.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Amoxicillin (no penicillin allergy)
formulations: Oral suspension/solution 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL, 500 mg/5 mL (standard and sugar-free) x 100 mL
no.route: Oral with food or water (capsules swallowed whole)
no.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

next.title: Back‑up antibiotic strategy (perforation)
actions: Provide a back‑up prescription to start if no improvement after 2–3 days or if symptoms worsen.
Advise on self-care and analgesia; discuss red flags and when to start antibiotics.
next.followUp: Return if no improvement within 3–5 days or earlier if worsening.

no.title: Amoxicillin (no penicillin allergy)
formulations: Oral suspension/solution 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL, 500 mg/5 mL (standard and sugar-free) x 100 mL
no.route: Oral with food or water (capsules swallowed whole)
no.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Child under 2 with bilateral infection
no.question: Is the child under 2 years AND infection in both ears?

next.title: Back‑up antibiotic strategy (bilateral <2 years)
actions: Provide a back‑up prescription to start if no improvement after 2–3 days or if symptoms worsen.
Advise on self-care and analgesia; ensure carers understand when to start.
next.followUp: Return if no improvement within 3–5 days or earlier if worsening.

no.title: Severity and duration
no.question: Does the patient meet ANY: severe symptoms (clinician global impression) OR symptoms >3 days?

yes.title: Moderate–severe symptoms without perforation
yes.question: Consider topical analgesic ear drops and/or oral antibiotics?
actions: Consider phenazone 40 mg/g with lidocaine 10 mg/g ear drops (Otigo) up to 7 days, plus self-care, subject to PGD inclusion/exclusion.
If antibiotics indicated (shared decision-making) choose strategy: immediate vs back-up.

next.title: Penicillin allergy?
next.question: Is there a reported penicillin allergy?

next.title: Back‑up antibiotic strategy (delayed)
actions: Provide a back‑up prescription to start if symptoms do not improve within 2–3 days or worsen at any time.
Explain when and how to use the prescription; return if concerns.
next.followUp: Return if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment; use prescription if agreed triggers occur.

otigo_details.product: Otigo (phenazone 40 mg/g + lidocaine hydrochloride 10 mg/g) ear drops
otigo_details.indication: Local symptomatic relief of pain from AOM in children ≥1 year and <18 years with moderate–severe symptoms and pain not controlled with regular paracetamol/ibuprofen
otigo_details.dose: Instil 4 drops up to three times daily into the affected ear(s)
otigo_details.duration: Until symptoms resolve or up to 7 days
otigo_details.route: Topical into external auditory canal; warm bottle between hands before use
advice: Use PIL and Medicines for Children guidance for administration.
Consider only when PGD inclusion criteria are met and exclusions ruled out.

yes.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Mild symptoms
actions: Offer self-care and pain relief (paracetamol/ibuprofen with age/weight-appropriate dosing).
Antibiotics are not routinely indicated; consider no prescription or a delayed prescription based on shared decision-making.
advice: Most AOM lasts ~1 week; >80% recover without antibiotics within 2–3 days from presentation.
no.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Acute otitis media less likely
actions: Consider alternative diagnosis and proceed appropriately.
Onward referral to GP or other provider if needed.

no.title: Acute otitis media less likely
actions: Consider alternative diagnosis and proceed appropriately.
Onward referral to GP or other provider if needed.

Otigo.name: Otigo (phenazone 40 mg/g + lidocaine hydrochloride 10 mg/g) ear drops
Otigo.indication: Local symptomatic relief of pain from AOM in children ≥1 year and <18 years with moderate–severe symptoms where pain not controlled with regular paracetamol/ibuprofen
Otigo.dose: 4 drops up to three times daily into affected ear(s)
Otigo.duration: Until symptoms resolve or up to 7 days
Otigo.route: Topical into external auditory canal; warm bottle before use

Amoxicillin.name: Amoxicillin
Amoxicillin.indication: AOM in children ≥1 year and <18 years
Amoxicillin.duration: 5 days; start immediately and complete course
Amoxicillin.route: Oral with food or water; capsules swallowed whole
notes: Indicated if: under 2 years with bilateral AOM, symptoms >3 days, severe symptoms, or AOM with otorrhoea.

Clarithromycin.name: Clarithromycin
Clarithromycin.indication: AOM where amoxicillin not appropriate due to hypersensitivity
Clarithromycin.duration: 5 days; start immediately and complete course
Clarithromycin.route: Oral with water; with or without food. For suspension, drink juice/water after to avoid bitter after-taste.

Erythromycin.name: Erythromycin
Erythromycin.indication: AOM in young people aged 16–17 who are pregnant or pregnancy suspected AND penicillin allergy
Erythromycin.duration: 5 days; start immediately and complete course
Erythromycin.route: Oral with water just before or with food

selfCare: Analgesia: paracetamol or ibuprofen as per age/weight dosing schedules.
Adequate fluids, rest, and comfort measures.
education: Over 80% recover without antibiotics within 2–3 days from presentation.
Share NICE information on antibiotics and when they may (or may not) be needed.
safetyNet: Seek medical help urgently if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, the child becomes very unwell, or no improvement after 2–3 days of antibiotics.
Return to community pharmacy for reassessment if no improvement within 3–5 days.
